awd_titl_txt: Vapor-Liquid-Ice: Exploring Water's Phase Transitions Far from Equilibrium
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) and Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) Programs of the Division of Chemistry are funding Professor Barbara Wyslouzil at Ohio State University (OSU) to exploring how water moves between the vapor, liquid and solid states.  Two phenomena that are being studied are supercooled water and supersaturated water vapor.  Liquid water generally changes into ice solid water) below 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius), but sometimes it remains in liquid form well below the freezing temperature (hence the name "supercooled").  Similarly, sometimes, water can remain in vapor form well above the concentration at which it should form a liquid (condense); this point is called "supersaturated."  Professor Wyslouzil and her research team are using a supersonic nozzle, infrared spectroscopy, and x-ray scattering tools to determine the limits to which water vapor can be supersaturated and liquid water supercooled, and how fast the eventual freezing and condensation occur. These questions are important in the atmosphere where the state of water affects both the ability of clouds to bounce sunlight back into space and the chemical reactions taking place within the clouds. In industry, understanding when water condenses is important to developing efficient energy extraction schemes. Professor Wyslouzil participates in OSU's Breakfast of Science Champions program and collaborates with the Steam Factory, an OSU initiative to promote interdisciplinary collaboration across Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Math.

To investigate phase transitions involving supercooled and supersaturated water, the Wyslouzil group has developed a transportable supersonic nozzle apparatus that is easily integrated with a broad range of analytical tools. In her lab, standard methods include static pressure measurements to characterize the flow and infrared spectroscopy to quantify the distribution of the condensable fraction among the vapor, liquid and solid states. To fully characterize the size of the aerosol droplets and their crystal structure requires spatially resolved small- and wide- angle X-ray scattering (SAXS/WAXS) experiments and these are made at national user facilities. The high transformation rates that are measured also approach those that can be directly investigated using molecular simulations. Experiments, exploring how water far from equilibrium behaves and/or transforms, are critical to advancing our understanding of the phase diagram of water, the validity  of advanced water models, the anomalous behavior of this fascinating compound, and for developing
accurate models of natural and industrial processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The phases of water, and the transitions between them, play critical roles in natural and industrial processes. The degree to which liquid water can be supercooled, the rate at which it solidifies, and the phases – amorphous solid, crystalline ice, or clathrate – that form in the presence or absence of other molecules, are fundamental and relevant questions for both industry and atmospheric science. Controlling water vapor condensation in steam turbines is key to efficient energy extraction. Compared to simple liquids, liquid water also exhibits a broad range of anomalous physical properties that are often amplified as it is supercooled. Experiments, exploring how water far from equilibrium behaves and/or transforms, are critical to advancing our understanding of the phase diagram of water, the validity of advanced water models, the anomalous behavior of this fascinating compound, and for developing accurate models of natural and industrial processes.

Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of the proposed research was to explore water’s phase transitions under conditions that are far from equilibrium. Questions of specific interest that were addressed include: (1) How does the nature of nucleation from the vapor phase change as the temperature decreases and supersaturations become extreme? (2) How does clustering of an alcohol affect the onset of aqueous-alcohol binary nucleation from the vapor phase? (3) How does the presence of short chain alcohols affect water condensation and freezing?

To address the first question, we compared vapor phase nucleation data generated inside our supersonic nozzles – where the process should be controlled by a free energy barrier – to data generated by our collaborator in a post-nozzle flow – where particle formation approaches the collisional limit. Overlapping experimental conditions were possible for CO2, and the combined experiments, together with a kinetic model using rate constants from high-level quantum chemical calculations, provided a comprehensive picture of new particle formation as nucleation transitions from a barrier dominated process to the collisional limit. The second and third questions were addressed in experiments with water and a series of straight chain and branched alcohols containing one to six carbons. In all cases the presence of the alcohol makes it easier for particles to form, i.e. mixed particles can form at higher temperatures than pure particles.  This is largely because the free energy of the smallest clusters is reduced by the incorporation of the alcohol. When the water nanodroplets containing up to 6 mole% of selected short chain alcohols (1-pentanol, 1-hexanol, 3-pentanol and 3-hexanol) froze, partitioning of the alcohols to the surface ensured there was very little effect for concentrations below ~3 – 4 mol %. Furthermore, when droplets froze, the ice that formed appeared identical to that formed from pure water.  A series of molecular dynamics simulations suggested that straight chain alcohols can enhance the formation of the six-membered rings near the droplet surface more effectively than branched alcohols.

Broader Impact

Our work addressed fundamental problems in aerosol science by employing a set of highly integrated experimental techniques, ranging from pressure measurements to small angle scattering and InfraRed spectroscopy, with molecular modeling techniques. The approach provides a new way to quantitatively investigate the freezing transitions with extremely clean samples under conditions that are far from equilibrium, and a powerful set of experimental tools that probe conditions very close to the still idealized requirements of simulations.
